bibl.note: This is a letter dated May 18, 1838 from James King to his son Henry King. He instructs his son on the virtues of being a good soldier, as well as his various duties and responsibilities.

div.p: Before this time you have reached Calhone, the plaice place of rendezvous, and by this I presume you have learnt a little of the reedements rudiments of a soaldier soldier in camps; therefore if I give you a short treatice treatise on the duties, acts, and performaces performances of a soaldier, it will be more perseptible perceptible to your understanding than would have been on any former occasion.

It is expected your officers will instruct you on all the various duties of a soaldier in camp; also, the rules & regulations, by law that are necessarily established, to keep good order and disciplin discipline in the army. They will also inform you of the pennilities penalties and punnishmints punishments annexed by violating and disobaying disobeying such laws and regulation. Whilst learning what the various duties of a soaldier are; you should bear in mind, the soaldier that prides in his duty, will be always ready and chearfully cheerfully perform it, whilst health permits,. therefore in I incourage encourage you, by the love of duty to purform perform the part of a valient valiant
Soaldier soldier . In treating on the love of duty I would not have you to think, you are to be at every bodies beck and call, and to do any thing that might call on you to do, no; that would show two much good natured ignorence ignorance ;
I would have you to inspire confidence & stability in your self, and courage to suffer no imposition in any way.

I have been an old soaldier, and have seen, and know, many imprudent acts and deeds by soaldiers soldiers in the army; such as many have recieved received severe punishment, others, with their carracters characters so defaimed defamed that they bare Since I come in town I understand you are have all arrived at Calhone saft safe , and are all well, In presenting my respects to Capt Captain Yoakum tell him if I would be pleased he would write to me- JaMKing

My sone son you are young; and unexperienced, let me treat the to be cautious, and act the part of an honourably Soaldier. Soldier

When I parted with you and the company my eyes ware were overflowing; not that I was sorry, but overjoyed with the gratification of seeing so much patriotism and valour valor , inhailed inhaled in the youthful sones sons of Tennessee, by the lighted kindled flaimes flames of the old heroes of Seventy Six.-

Your officers are gentllmen gentlemen of respectibility respectability and I have no doubt but they will use their best efforts to provide for your general welfare, and should any of you be sick, I have no doubt but they would give all posible possible attention therefore I feal feel not the least uneasy about your welfair welfare , and I flatter myself you have prudence and care enough to conduct yourself in a respectable & orderly manner so much so, as to merrit merit and recieve receive the applause of your officers & good will of the Soaldiers soldiers

What I have written I intend for you William & Albert to peruse, and regard it as matter of importance, coming from one who has had considerably considerable experience in the service of his country. If any others wish interested to perusing it let them do so.

I wish you William & Albert assist each other as occasion requires, and act generously & fealingly feelingly towards each other-
My son, your mother has much feeling for you William and Albert on account of your youthful age, for fear you will be headless and careless, and get in bad habits; this I flatter myself will not be the case; she is purfectly perfectly
reconsiled reconciled at your going, and are proud to think you have the pride of a soaldier, and cherrish cherish the hopes that you will never degrad degrade it- You Your brothers and sisters are often talking about you and wondering what you are about, and how your are doing, Charley are often talking about brother Henry's goin going to shoot the Indians-

Myself your mother, Brothers & Sisters, Sarah and Martha are all in good health, Your Grandmother's, Your Aunt Jane & friends generally are all well, my respects to Snell & tell them I hear of no complaining at their homes- My respects and well wishes to Capt Captain Yocum & Officers, and to the soaldiers generally,-

Your mother Brothers & sisters, Sarah & Martha joines joins me in love and well wishes for your's Williams & Aberts safety welfare and safe return home, write to me let me know where to direct letters to you, and what are the general movemts movements of the army
